subject: Once More, the Calendars
event: It's now March, and I think... hope... that we are almost done with the calendar business. Les Dabel has assured me that everyone who bought and paid for a calendar has now been sent one (some have been sent two, or even three, he says, in cases where the first one never arrived). The international shipments may not yet have been delivered in all cases, overseas airmail being what it is, but all of them are on the way. This leaves only the signed calendars. And no, those have not yet arrived here for signing. Let me say once again that the minute they turn up, I will post it here. (Let me also say, once again, that I will NOT be signing any 2010 calendars. Les, Ernst, please do not offer any 2010 signed versions, I do not want to go through this again) (And that's March, FWIW. Arya and the dragon skulls. Komarck is amazing. I do hope enough of you nominated him for that Hugo, he deserves a spot on the ballot).

comments.article: I suppose I'll book mark this post and wait until Friday to see if my Snow print and calendar arrive because never got a response from Les or the other two at Dabel Bros. I emailed. :(

Just for the record, I'm doing everything possible to see that everyone who bought a calendar receives one, and posting regular updates on the situation here.

However, I have absolutely nothing to do with these prints that the Dabel Brothers are selling. I have never mentioned them here or on my website, and I am not part of that arrangement. So any problems with the prints are just between you and the Dabels.

Sorry, but there's a limit to how much I can take on.
comments.subject: prints

comments.article:
The calendar was supposed to be distributed by Diamond, and therefore should have been available through comic shops and bookstores serviced by them... but it's now so late that I'm not sure that Diamond will bother. Who buys a calendar in March?

It will definitely NOT be available through the chains.
comments.subject: Re: A simple question:

comments.article: My Amazon order was cancelled after months of waiting, which is kinda sad... I wanted this calendar mostly because of its fantastic art. :(
Same here. I was very disappointed. I never would have thought Amazon would be stiffed. *sighs*

...wow. That is absolutely gorgeous.

Also, I was wondering about the in-store option for the calendar. I guess it's probably not gonna happen? Sad.

I'll definitely be buying it next year, though.
that really is a fantastic piece of artwork there

I received mine today. Spectacular! There is not a single "month" that I do not like. They're all so vivid and alive. Dany's is breathtaking (as is Sansa in the snow.)

My favorite, however, is the one that was posted: Arya underneath King's Landing.

Well done. Now I'm off to crow to all my friends about it. (prances)
I love that you have digital copies of all these images.  If I can't have a calendar, I'll at least have cool desktop wallpaper.

Really, you shouldn't have to double as their (non-existing) customer service. But the more images you post, the more I keep my fingers crossed that the calendars are on their way... however it's vexing since I've sent half a dozen mails and haven't got any reply yet, if it wasn't for this blog I'd have given up already.
However I'm a hopeless optimist.

Hey guys. I am back and will be checking emails and messages on here to see who still needs help getting their products. Thanks.



Les D
comments.subject: Sorry I am back

comments.article: Here's a thought Les, how about RESPONDING to some of those emails that you've been getting.  For every 10 I send you, I get one back that tells me you're looking into it and the nothing, for another month.  I see people on your forum are now demanding refunds and reporting u guys to the BBB.  Can't blame them.
comments.subject: Re: Sorry I am back

comments.article: Just wanted to say that i got my calendar for Christmas. Here's for one that made it one time!
I just wanted to say I got my calendar (US, unsigned, obviously) back in late Dec, and its beautiful.  I hope that next year, it goes much better overall!

I just wanted to say something to you Mr. Martin, I cannot thank you enough for these books. I started reading them years ago and a few months ago downloaded them from Audible.com. I listen to them nearly every day. I am patiently waiting till the next book comes out... but I am dying to know something... if you would be so kind to either give a hint or tell me where I can find it.

Who is Jon's mother and father? I refuse to believe Ned is his father, maybe I am idealist, but I think his personal ethics to high to dishonor hi wife by lying with another woman once he took his vows. There is huge heated debate between many of my friends! We are dying to know who is right!
comments.subject: Not a post on hurrying the book :-)

comments.article: It must be an amazing feeling to see your words painted so vividly. Congratulations.
comments.subject: Amazing

comments.article:
Agreed.

One thing that's dawned on me recently is that outside of Tolkien's Middle-Earth and perhaps Robert E. Howard's Conan, I'm not sure of a author who's had so many top-flight artists interpret his fantasy work as GRRM has had.
comments.subject: Re: Amazing

comments.article:
Holy crap...
It's amazing work. May is something to behold.
comments.subject: Got mine the other day...

comments.article:
Hello!

I ordered two through Amazon. Will they be getting them? They cancelled my order but I still really want one. If I at least get one then I can share.

Let me know. I've tried ordering from the Dabel brother site and it won't let me order them. I went there right after Amazon cancelled. Just let me know where I can get one. :D

Thanks

Marlene

Neil Gaiman just reminisced in his Journal about the Worldcon he visited 21 years ago, where one of the great things he remembered was pitching a Wildcard character to you. Apparently he was supposed to live in dreams...
http://journal.neilgaiman.com/2009/03/waiting-for-stephin.html

And I just finished reading your short memoirs intersected between your collection of short stories spanning your amazing career, about growing up a comic book fan and writing for fanzines.

I just LOVE the fact that my idols and heroes of Fantasy and Comics are such total geeks themselves. Never change.

Absolutely stunning illustration BTW.
You both deserve a Hugo.
comments.subject: Shoutout by Gaiman

comments.article: I'm still waiting for mine.  I'm beginning to think I'll end up seeing all the images here on your not-a-blog before I see them in the calendar and I agree that the artwork is amazing.  Frankly, I'd rather purchase all these in poster form and have them framed.

I had tried to order in the past but was unsucessful...I still would love one for the same reason: the artwork.

Any direction you can give us to order "leftovers" is appreciated!
comments.subject: Reiterating others:  I would love to order one now

comments.article: Hopefully my callendar will arive soon then, i got a reply from Les 6 weeks asgo. but when i asked about an update last week i didn't get a reply... and the parcel i mailed to Canada last week, arrived within 8 days. So a fast delivery to and from North America is possible...

Mr Martin, I loved your response to your critics, detractors, et al. of 2/19.
And surely they must realize they're only shooting themselves in the foot? There's nothing worse than people bitching at you to make you not want to do something. Or rush it out malformed and disgusting like an aborted alien fetus and think "Well there you go, enjoy!"

As for going to conventions, I've met Peter S Beagle 2 years in a row now at Otakon in Baltimore. Convention-going authors are rock. Star.
Much love and I can in fact wait for Dance.


P.S. If I may suggest some alternatives to re-reading Ice and Fire and anguishing over cliffhangers:
I'm currently 3 books into...
Glen Cook's Chronicles of the Black Company.
I think fans of GRRM's series might enjoy these too.

And for something else long and wonderful and full of detail, but not the same vein of fantasy:
Jonathan Strange and Mr Norrell by Susanna Clarke.
Black Company and Song of Ice and Fire are both set in different worlds, full of battle and political intrigue. This book is set in England, if that particular brand of Old World magic had really existed, but just died out. It's a dark faerie tale, not a sword and sorcery epic. But it's alternate history during the war with Napoleon but with magicians, what's not to like?

I'm also going to throw Lord of Light by Roger Zelazny out there, along with The Anubis Gates by Tim Powers, and curiouser and curiouser? Watership Down by Richard Adams.
"Watership Down is a remarkable tale of exile and survival, of heroism and leadership...the epic novel of a group of adventurers who desert their doomed city, and venture forth against all odds on a quest for a new home, a sturdier future..."
What turns most people off is it's not about human beings but about rabbits. It's got the rabbit version of Nazi Germany though! Infiltrations, rescues, escapes, war and life and death.

comments.upictitle: The great, the knowledgable, the one, the only...: pic#111100213
comments.article:
I seldom post on this thing, but I usually read it.

Motion on The Black Company STRONGLY seconded. Glen Cook is a gem in the trove of modern day fantasy.

I too can wait for the Dance.

As a writer, I can only empathize- hell, I can barely finish a short story without blowing through 2 packs of cigarettes and a headache. A Novel can only be infinitely rougher.

Julius II needs to relax, eh Michelangelo? Harharhar
Ah! We tried to get ours on Amazon... is there anywhere else to buy it?

Amazon cancelled my order as well.  I was very sad about that.  My work calendar for the past several years depicts wolves.  (I love wolves.)  I thought this year ASOIAF would be a great change.  But it was not meant to be!  Sniff!
